contentrichtext.text: [[File:KoShinEtsu-region Small.png|thumb|Koshin'etsu region]] {{Nihongo|'''Kōshin'etsu'''|甲信越}} is a subregion of the [[Chūbu region]] in [[Japan]] consisting of Tokyo, its environs and central-eastern Honshu.<ref>Nakayama, Shigeru, Kunio Gotō and Hitoshi Yoshioka. (2006). ''A Social History of Science and Technology in Contemporary Japan: Transformation period, 1970-1979,'' p. 423.</ref> The area encompasses [[Yamanashi prefecture|Yamanashi]], [[Nagano prefecture|Nagano]], and [[Niigata prefecture|Niigata]] prefectures.<ref>''Nihon Ginkō''. (1990). ''Bank of Japan Monetary and Economic Studies,'' Vols. 8-9, p. 129.</ref> The name Kōshin'etsu is a composite formed from the names of [[Old provinces of Japan|old provinces]] which are adjacent to each other — [[Kai province|Kai (now Yamanashi)]], [[Shinano province|Shinano (now Nagano)]] and [[Echigo province|Echigo (now Niigata)]]. The region is surrounded by the [[Sea of Japan]] to its north west, [[Hokuriku region]] to its west, [[Tōkai region]] to its south west, [[Kantō region]] to its south east, and [[Tōhoku region]] to its north east. The name for this geographic area is usually combined with Kantō region (as in "Kantō-Kōshin'etsu"<ref name="jsnm">"Abstracts from the 25th Kanto-Koshinetsu regional meeting of the Japanese Society of Nuclear Medicine" (JSNM), ''Japanese Journal of Nuclear Medicine'' (Jpn J Nucl Med) 23(10):1503-1511, October 1986.</ref>); and it is sometimes combined with Hokuriku region (as in "Kantō-Kōshin'etsu-Hokuriku"<ref>"29th Kanto-Koshinetsu-Hokuriku Regional meeting of the Japanese Circulation Society," ''Japan Circulation Journal'' (1963), Vol. 27, No. 12, p. 907.</ref> or "Hokuriku-Kōshin'etsu"<ref>Nakagawa, Naofumi ''et al.'' (2010). {{Google books|FejqAv4YQfgC|''The Japanese Macaques,'' p. 144.|page=144}}</ref>). ==Corporate usage== *[[Nippon Telegraph & Telephone]] directories categorize phone numbers by region, including the Koshin'etsu area.<ref>''Nihon Denshin Denwa Kabushiki Kaisha.'' (1995). ''City Source English Telephone Directory: Greater Tokyo, Tokyo/Yokohama/Chiba, Nagoya, Sapporo, Sendai business directory,'' p. 887.</ref> *The [[Japanese Society of Nuclear Medicine]] categorizes its membership by region, including the Kanto-Koshinetsu region.<ref name="jsnm"/> *In Japan, the Children's Cancer Registry program is administered by seven National Children's Medical Registration Centers, including Kanto-KoShinEstsu.<ref>Watanabe, Shō '' et al.''
